Author: GeneReddit123

Comment: We'll see how this goes, often the problem with these privatized developments is that they end up with an issue for things like sanitation or sewage: mostly companies just push the costs onto the municipality, but when the company is footing the bill themselves now they cut corners, such as only pumping the sewage away just far enough not to offend the wealthy inhabitants of the settlement instead of paying for a treatment plant  Maybe they can make illegal pipes that pump the sewage into a nearby counties system so that the government there can deal with the cost, or just truck it away.  EDIT: and it turns out this is the exact fight they're having.  https://www.borderreport.com/news/environment/spacex-wants-to-dump-treated-sewage-water-into-texas-south-bay-coastal-preserve/  > SpaceX wants to dump treated sewage water into Texas’ South Bay coastal preserve

Author: ergzay

Comment: The example I was actually thinking of was actually Gurgaon in India  https://www.businessinsider.com/gurgaon-the-town-without-a-government-2016-3  It's a company city, where sewage is basically pumped to the edge of town where it's dumped into the river. Highrises surrounded by some of the worst slums. Some people think the town is great, if you've got the money, but the sustainability is near zero.
Author: cipheron

Comment: FYI it's not sewage that the article is talking about, it's waste water. Waste water that was effectively clean water that's pumped through pipes to blast up under the bottom of the rocket to protect it from blast damage during rocket launches. It becomes "waste water" from a political standpoint as soon as it goes through pipes even if the water is still clean.
